title: 109_hr4285
content: The Act may be cited as the "Detection Canine Augmentation Act of 2005". The Congress recognizes the importance of detection canines in homeland security for detecting explosives, narcotics, concealed humans, and cadavers in various locations where detection technologies are not feasible. There is a shortage of detection canines available to support law enforcement at all levels. Detection canines are crucial for homeland security, but there is a shortage of them available to assist law enforcement. Congress has authorized more Border Patrol agents without increasing the number of detection canines deployed with them. Canines have been deployed to airports, but the Transportation Security Administration needs to expand its training program to deploy them to mass transit systems. Urban search and rescue canines were effective during Hurricanes Katrina and Rita. Urban search and rescue canines and cadaver detection canines were effectively used in the Gulf Coast region during Hurricanes Katrina and Rita. Various federal agencies, including the Bureau of United States Customs and Border Protection, utilize detection canines for securing National Special Security Events, protecting Federal buildings, and safeguarding sea ports. A hearing held by the Subcommittee on Management, Integration, and Oversight of the Committee on Homeland Security discussed the use of detection canines in support of homeland security activities. Several Federal agencies, a local transit police department, a private canine security company, and a university-based canine training center highlighted a shortage of trained detection canines during a hearing by the Subcommittee on Management, Integration, and Oversight of the Committee on Homeland Security. Increasing the number of trained detection canines. The Secretary of Homeland Security must increase the number of trained detection canines in various agencies by at least 25% in fiscal years 2007 through 2011, subject to available appropriations. This includes Customs and Border Protection, Transportation Security Administration, Coast Guard, Secret Service, Federal Protective Service, and Federal Emergency Management Agency. The Secretary of Homeland Security must increase the number of trained detection canine teams available to various agencies by at least 25% in fiscal years 2007 through 2011. This includes Customs and Border Protection, Transportation Security Administration, Coast Guard, Secret Service, Federal Protective Service, and Federal Emergency Management Agency. The detection canine teams are deployed to ensure their availability as needed in emergencies. SEC. 4. COORDINATION AND ENHANCEMENT OF CANINE TRAINING PROGRAMS. The Secretary of Homeland Security is required to coordinate canine training programs for various security missions, utilize existing resources efficiently, and explore partnerships to increase the number of trained detection canines available to law enforcement agencies. The Secretary of Homeland Security must report to Congress within 120 days on plans to coordinate and consolidate canine training programs, including increasing coordination with other federal agencies like the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives. The Secretary of Homeland Security is required to prioritize increasing the use of domestically bred canines for counter-terrorism purposes, such as protecting ports of entry and the US border. They must also collaborate with other federal agencies and the Office of Management and Budget to promote domestic breeding and streamline canine procurement to reduce costs.
